issue.title: The site can't provide a secure connection: https://localhost:4433
issue.body:
Hello Team,
I have bult the chromium demo un ubuntu server but at the last step i have recived the error "The site can't provide a secure connection". Client ans server dont support the common ssl.
I am able to successfully rin the TLS connection in boringssl

![BoringSSL_passed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28886647/85852131-9f7a6a00-b7cd-11ea-94f6-c074d073caff.jpg)
![Error on local host](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28886647/85852186-b7ea8480-b7cd-11ea-97aa-a303e6a5574b.jpg)

comment.body:
Hi @yogitagolhani  - great to see you kept working on this. When you say 

> I am able to successfully rin the TLS connection in boringssl 

do you mean to have done a successful command-line (BoringSSL) TLS-interaction with your test server? Could you show a dump of that, please?

Another idea coming to my mind when seeing what you're trying to do, could you try another KEX than 'oqs_kem_default', say 'frodo640aes' (just in case the `liboqs` default algorithm is not the same)? In any case, I'm sure @xvzcf has more and better ideas, too.

comment.body: Hi @yogitagolhani, can you pass the `-curves p256_frodo640aes` option to `bssl server` and then try to connect to it using Chromium?

issue.title: CMake ProjectConfig.cmake
issue.body:
Hi!
I am integrating liboqs into another project where I am heavily relying on CMake's `*Config.cmake` files via `find_package()`, whenever that's possible for my dependencies.

Since liboqs has switched to CMake for building, I am wondering if you are planning to support mentioned configuration files.
These would also greatly benefit the packaging for various GNU/Linux Distributions, where liboqs could be installed via the global package manager.

References:
* https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/community/-/wikis/doc/tutorials/How-to-create-a-ProjectConfig.cmake-file
* https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/module/CMakePackageConfigHelpers.html
* https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/configure_file.html#command:configure_file

Is this feature on your schedule?

comment.body: As the project is still at an experimental stage (see [this](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/766#issuecomment-646186046)), we currently have no plans of adding `liboqs` to Linux package managers. That being said, adding a `ProjectConfig.cmake` for other purposes is certainly something I intend to look into.

issue.title: Always create $(DESTDIR)/lib during make install, even on Windows
issue.body:
Cross-compiling for Windows deposits binaries in bin, not lib.

Commit 72ea3e9 added rules to copy `liboqs.a` to OpenSSL's lib directory for development purposes, but when cross-compiling for Windows, lib hasn't been created yet.

As a result, during `make install`, `liboqs.a` ends up copied and named `lib` in $(DESTDIR). This later causes a failure when it tries to create a directory there called `lib` only to find a file exists with that name.

This commit causes `lib` to always be created in the `install_runtime_libs` recipe, and `liboqs.a` ends up in the right place. The `mkdir-p.pl` script doesn't fail if it tries to create a directory that already exists as a directory, and `make install` succeeds.

comment.body: I wouldn't have expected it either! But now we know the template is used whenever *nix is the _build_ platform, regardless of target.

issue.title: Update cross-compiling instructions for Windows in README.md
issue.body: OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS has to be OFF in the cross-compiling scenario, or CMake will fail.

comment.body: I've opened #775, since that way I can also mention the OQS-OpenSSL cross-compilation wiki should be updated as well, if and when CPU_EXTENSIONS supports cross-compilation.

issue.title: liboqs fails to build on Ubuntu 16.04
issue.body:
Hi all,

I tried to build liboqs on Ubuntu 16.04 with openssl 1.1.1c (I built openssl from source and installed it in /usr/local/ssl) as below,

cd build
cmake -GNinja .. -DOPENSSL_ROOT_DIR=/usr/local/ssl/
ninja
[5/1393] Building C object src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/mzd_additional.c.o
FAILED: src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/mzd_additional.c.o 
/usr/bin/cc  -DOPTIMIZED_LINEAR_LAYER_EVALUATION -DPICNIC_STATIC -DREDUCED_ROUND_KEY_COMPUTATION -DWITH_AVX2 -DWITH_KECCAK_X4 -DWITH_KKW -DWITH_LOWMC_128_128_20 -DWITH_LOWMC_192_192_30 -DWITH_LOWMC_256_256_38 -DWITH_OPT -DWITH_SSE2 -DWITH_ZKBPP -Iinclude -I../src/sig/picnic/external -I../src/sig/picnic/external/sha3 -I../src/sig/picnic/external/sha3/avx2 -fPIC -fvisibility=hidden   -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -Wno-missing-braces -std=gnu11 -MMD -MT src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/mzd_additional.c.o -MF src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/mzd_additional.c.o.d -o src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/mzd_additional.c.o   -c ../src/sig/picnic/external/mzd_additional.c
../src/sig/picnic/external/mzd_additional.c: In function ‘oqs_sig_picnic_mzd_copy_s256_256’:
../src/sig/picnic/external/mzd_additional.c:157:44: internal compiler error: in convert_move, at expr.c:315
   BLOCK(dst, 0)->w256 = CONST_BLOCK(src, 0)->w256;
                                            ^
Please submit a full bug report,
with preprocessed source if appropriate.
See <file:///usr/share/doc/gcc-5/README.Bugs> for instructions.
[9/1393] Building C object src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c.o
FAILED: src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c.o 
/usr/bin/cc  -DOPTIMIZED_LINEAR_LAYER_EVALUATION -DPICNIC_STATIC -DREDUCED_ROUND_KEY_COMPUTATION -DWITH_AVX2 -DWITH_KECCAK_X4 -DWITH_KKW -DWITH_LOWMC_128_128_20 -DWITH_LOWMC_192_192_30 -DWITH_LOWMC_256_256_38 -DWITH_OPT -DWITH_SSE2 -DWITH_ZKBPP -Iinclude -I../src/sig/picnic/external -I../src/sig/picnic/external/sha3 -I../src/sig/picnic/external/sha3/avx2 -fPIC -fvisibility=hidden   -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -Wno-missing-braces -std=gnu11 -MMD -MT src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c.o -MF src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c.o.d -o src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c.o   -c ../src/sig/picnic/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c
../src/sig/picnic/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c: In function ‘oqs_sig_picnic_mpc_matrix_mul_s256_128’:
../src/sig/picnic/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c:1305:27: internal compiler error: in convert_move, at expr.c:315
       mask2               = block_masks[(matrix_byte >> 0) & 0xf].w256;
                           ^
Please submit a full bug report,
with preprocessed source if appropriate.
See <file:///usr/share/doc/gcc-5/README.Bugs> for instructions.
[10/1393] Building C object src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/sha3/avx2/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c.o
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.

What is the supported Ubuntu version for liboqs?

Thanks,

/Kaiduan

comment.body: @kaiduanx Thanks for the complete report. To answer your question: We presently actively support/test Ubuntu 18.04. I think the issue you report is with the compiler version, though: Which gcc version do you have?

issue.title: Update cross-compiling instructions for Windows in README.md
issue.body: OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS has to be OFF in the cross-compiling scenario, or CMake will fail.

../src/sig/picnic/external/picnic2_simulate_mul.c:1305:27: internal compiler error: in convert_move, at expr.c:315
       mask2               = block_masks[(matrix_byte >> 0) & 0xf].w256;
                           ^
Please submit a full bug report,
with preprocessed source if appropriate.
See <file:///usr/share/doc/gcc-5/README.Bugs> for instructions.
[10/1393] Building C object src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/sha3/avx2/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c.o
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.

What is the supported Ubuntu version for liboqs?

Thanks,

/Kaiduan

comment.body: We haven't tested on gcc-5 for a while now, and if memory serves it indeed has compilation errors that we decided not to resolve.  Kaiduan, can you try a more recent version of gcc?  We test with gcc-7 and gcc-8.

[10/1393] Building C object src/sig/picnic/CMakeFiles/picnic.dir/external/sha3/avx2/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c.o
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.

What is the supported Ubuntu version for liboqs?

Thanks,

/Kaiduan

comment.body: I upgraded my Ubuntu to 18.04, the problem is gone. Thanks @dstebila and @baentsch
